captions.text:
Good morning, Hank, it's Tuesday. So worldwide,
more than 6 million children died in 2013,

which is horrible and unjust and unacceptable.
But it's also the lowest that number has been

in quite a while, even though the world population
has like steadily increased. Like, Hank, when

do you think the last time was that the world
saw fewer than 6.3 million children die in

a year: 1975, when the population of the world
was 4 billion? 1900 when it was 1.6 billion?

No, in 1900 probably more than 8 million children
died. Earth has not seen a year with so few

child deaths in hundreds of years--maybe a
thousand years!

So, Hank, I'm a big fan of the Gates Foundation,
the organization set up by Bill and Melinda

Gates that is--favorite mission statement
ever-- devoted to the idea that all people

deserve the chance to live a healthy and productive
life. And Bill and Melinda just released this

fascinating letter highlighting three myths
about development--and yes, I can call them

Bill and Melinda. Perhaps you're not familiar
with the rule of twitter following (which

I just made up) whereby you can call anyone
you follow on twitter by their first name.

See also my acquaintances Barack, Beyonce,
and Ellen. Right, but anyway, Bill and Melinda's
three myths:

First, it is not true that poor countries
will forever be poor. Hank, I hear this all

the time, especially about Africa, that despite
their rich natural resources, "those countries"

are just "doomed" to stay poor. Well yeah,
no. I mean, for one thing, seven of the ten

fastest growing economies of the last five
years are in Africa. To quote Bill, "You should

look skeptically at anyone who treats an entire
continent as an undifferentiated mass of poverty

and disease." It is not fair that Bill Gates
gets to be both a billionaire and a good writer.

Okay, it's time to put aside personal jealousy
and return to statistics. Adjusted for inflation,

Botswana's income per person in 1960 was $383-it
is now $12,000: $48,000 for a family of four.

Now that's an extreme example, but this is
happening around the world--in the last fifty

years, income per person in India has quadrupled;
in Brazil, it has nearly quintupled.

The second myth is that foreign aid is a waste.
Okay, quick quiz--guess what percentage of

your countries budget is spent on foreign
aid. The answer is three percent--if you're

Norwegian. In the United States it's less
than one percent. And even with that small

investment, we've seen tremendous results:
twenty five years ago, there were 350,000

new cases of polio a year. Today, thanks to
the aid-funded polio eradication initiative,

there are fewer than 400. Malaria, and measles,
and TB have all declined dramatically, and

healthier kids go to school more, and then
they work more when they grow up than they
would if they were chronically ill or disabled.

And the last myth is that saving lives leads
to overpopulation. I hear this all the time

and it's just not true! Population growth
declines as infant mortality declines. All

over the world. It is that simple. To quote
Melinda, "We make the future sustainable when

we invest in the poor, not when we insist
upon their suffering." BOOM! The "boom" isn't
part of the quote, that is-that was my addition.

In short, Hank, these investments are showing
phenomenal returns, and the greatest risk

we face is abandoning our success because
we wrongly think of it as failure. I'm gonna

say it again: fewer children died in 2013
than in any year on record. And all this means,

just to be clear, a better world not only
for those living in poverty but also for the

rest of us. I know this is counter to a lot
of what you hear on the news, but wealthier

countries benefit when poor countries become
less poor. For one thing, there are more people

on the earth with the education and wellbeing
to make wonderful things, from paintings to

smartphone apps. But there are also more people
to buy the stuff that we make, whether that's

artificial lips or, for example, my novel
The Fault in Our Stars. Hank, the Brazilian

edition of TFIOS is called A Culpa E Das Estrelas--(he
said, butchering the Portuguese). Even though

I can't say the title of the book, it's sold
hundreds of copies in Brazil--it's more popular

there than in Germany or the UK. A country
once deemed incurably poor now has, by some

measures, a healthier book publishing landscape
than many countries in Europe. And it's not

just Brazilians who benefit from Brazil's
phenomenal growth--it's also young adult novelists
in Indianapolis.

So thanks to everyone in Brazil who's bought
my book and thanks to the Gates foundation

for decreasing world suck and busting those
myths. There's a link to Bill and Melinda's

letter in the dooblydoo; it really is worth
reading. Hank, I will see you on Friday.

comments.author: Sujit Singh

comments.text:
"Fewer children died in 2013 than in any year on record".  According to 
Unicef data, this has been true for every year after 1970.  This coincides 
nicely with the introduction of modified crops introduced by Norman Borlaug 
and company.  Additionally, the percentage of people living on less than $1 
a day has seen a similar decline.  This bodes well for developing nations, 
but in my opinion it will lead to catastrophic consequences.  More people 
making it to adulthood and more people making more money means more people 
consuming more resources.  Living on a planet that is almost unarguably 
tapped for resources as it is it seems unfathomable to imagine 7-10 billion 
people living even an eastern European standard of living.  The ecological 
impacts would likely be disastrous if the current global situation is any 
indication.﻿

comments.text:
It's counter-intuitive but it's true bud. Families in countries with high 
infant mortality have more children to compensate for the fact many of them 
will die before adulthood. This isn't accounting for the fact that high 
infant mortality almost always goes hand in hand with limited access to 
contraception, and the need to use one's children as a source of income or 
labour (in general, poor family planning). Hope this helps.

comments.author: Zion³

comments.text:
On overpopulation, I, personally, rarely see a calculation that is actually 
very simple.
if seven-billion people have one acre each (a square with measure 208 ft on 
a side), and there are 640 acres per sq. mile, then there are 10,937,500 
sq. miles (2.833*10^17 km) that would be in use, which is about one-fifth 
of Earth's land area.
But, if everyone lived in an area of 1/50 acre(a square with a measure of 
30 feet (~10 meters), and which is more than enough per person, considering 
that there are families and such), then there would be 50 people per acre, 
which takes the land use down by a factor of 50, lowering the measure to 
218750 sq. miles [566560 square km] (about the size of France).
In short, there cannot be such a problem as overpopulation at this time 
(theoretically), since, if the Earth were divided into equal portions, 
there would be more than enough room for everyone, everywhere.﻿

comments.author: gregbow

comments.text:
John's videos are usually well-balanced and well-researched, but this one 
is surprisingly one-sided.  Does aid work?  His answer is a categorical 
"yes" -- way too simple and way too strong.  What about 1) aid projects 
that fail (happens all the time), 2) aid projects that increase overall GNP 
but at the same time increase disparities in wealth between rich and poor, 
3) aid projects which end up doing evil things (like well-meaning Saudis 
giving money to extremist madrassas in places they'd never dare to travel 
themselves) and 4) historical trends of countries which have developed with 
and without aid.  John, if you're reading this, a few books that introduce 
some of the complexity are The White Man's Burden (Easterly), The End of 
Poverty (Sachs), and The Road to Hell (Maren).  Nerdfighters, the bottom 
line is, if you want to support charitable causes, support initiatives 
where you as a donor will have a long-term relationship with the recipients 
and where you (either by living in the community or traveling there 
regularly) can see the results (or lack thereof).﻿

One of the biggest challenges to overcoming poverty in developing countries 
is political stability. Africa's geography necessitates investments in 
infrastructure in order for it's wealth of mineral resources to reach 
international markets. The problem is that potential infrastructure will be 
expensive, meaning that as long as Africa's plethora of ethnic and 
religious groups continue to fire RPGs at each other, foreign investment 
will be a long ways away. Likewise political corruption and kleptocratic 
rule tend to be equally hostile to development in their own right.﻿

comments.author: Christian Hamrick

comments.text:
I was skeptical of the Botswana statistic, so I looked it up on a website 
that's friends to any statistician studying Development - CIA World 
Factbook. Botswana as of 2013 has a GDP/Capita of $16,400 (adjusted for 
purchasing power parity) which is just incredible. 

Although, man does it have a high Gini Index (3rd highest in the world at 
63) which makes me wonder if the GDP/Capita (PPP) hasn't been massively 
skewed in the average being taken (which is something you have to look out 
for studying development and globalisation) ﻿

comments.text:
I think the whole "foreign aid is a waste" argument is more about how

groups) outweigh donations by nations massively. Now, whether or not that 
is true IDK, nor do I know if that means we don't have to worry if 
countries stop giving foreign aid. I'm just saying what I heard (I don't 
really follow this kind of thing on the news; sorry). Do a video on that, 
maybe I guess?﻿

comments.author: Oliver Morgan

comments.text:
The most developed countries have decreasing demographics so helping poor 
countries to develop may actually help combat overpopulation, btw the 
decreasing demographics are attributed to gender equality and education - 
an educated citizen will most likely have intellectual aspirations and will 
seek to fulfill them therefore postponing on creating a family...  ﻿
comments.author: SoapySoul

comments.text:
Just because polio cases diminished in poor countries doesn't mean it was 
due to foreign aid. Correlation isn't the same thing as causation. Maybe - 
or better yet, probably - it was  due to changes from within those 
countries, in politics and education. As a brazilian I think I can say that 
little to none of our breakthroughs in the last 30 years was due to America 
or Europe. For those curious I'd recommend "Why nations fail" by Acemoglu 
and Robinson.﻿
comments.author: maria ramos

comments.text:
Not to mention how country growth is not the best sign of development. Just 
look at China that grows faster than most countries and where you're not 
even allowed to watch youtube...
comments.author: maria ramos

comments.text:
i thought the majority of 'Merica's foreign aid came in the form of weapons 
and arms, and some "peacekeeping" military personnel.﻿
comments.author: abstractfacts

comments.text: Young?﻿
comments.author: ross clark

comments.text:
Don't let the "fastest-growing economies" statistic fool you. The economies 
grow rapidly on paper in percentage terms because they are so small that 
any investment or development, no matter how slight, is a lot for them. A 
single new mine or road built in a place like Sierra Leone is a massive 
gain to them, when it would be at most a footnote to a country like the US.﻿
comments.author: Nonamearisto

comments.text:
Actually, The current theory goes: when you built a road in a country with 
just 2 roads (or open ruotes to other countries and previously isolated 
regions) you will enhance that economy much more than when a country that 
has 20924332 built another one.. This is because the country with 233232 
roads has a lot of road to commerce while the country that didn't have one 
(or has 2-3), now with one more the economy will expand greatly because 
yes, now there's another road for trucks to go and for a country with few 
roads.. that's a massive improvement.

I do get that this progress could be fragile.. But everything is fragile at 
that stage, normally countries gain more stability if the process continues 
without pausing and it's costant and that's the aim of the people helping.

Also, that argument is not really a real argument, you can't just say ohh 
all that they are doing is extracting resources, that implies that they 
don't have cities where there's commerce, that they are not building roads 
to connect the cities and that everyone live in tiny little villages where 
it is difficult to use the export money. Those 3 are truth (arguably not 
the second) up to a extent, cities in Africa are growing way faster than in 
other continents and while this growth is a fragile one it is still growth. 
And corruption takes a lot of the money from those revenues and while 
that's true, there's also a lot more pressure from NGO and goverments to 
stop that, I mean,we can just pressure the guys an take some legal action 
and that's it because the alternative is not doing any business with them.. 
And that would make their situation far worse.

To conclude, while a big fragile, progress is progress and for nations with 
little over 60-70 years on average, starting from rock bottom, they have a 
lot of road to covert.. The good thing is that normally when the proccess 
begins (in a stable way).. It is hard to stop.
comments.author: sergioccs74

comments.text:
i highly doubt the Chinese are going to un-pave the roads their money built 
in Angola (which btw yield a great deal of positive externality). And i 
doub NGOs are going to stop development projects all of a sudden. So no 
it's not "very very fragile". if the African nation in question has a 
stable government, then the extraction of resources comes back in the form 
of export revenue, which can then be used to develop the country in other 
areas. China can afford to be more generous because a) it has massive 
foreign reserves and b) it has to compete with other nations for these 
resources so ithas to present a better deal than what western counterparts 
have to offer. But that's not to say aid efforts from western and intll 
NGOs haven't been effective
comments.author: Doctor Witten

comments.text:
The progress, if you can call it that, is very, very fragile and very 
easily reversible. Most of the new infrastructure is set up to extract 
resources and send them to more developed countries, not to develop the 
country in terms of health, education, industry, or even service jobs.
comments.author: Nonamearisto

comments.text:
+Nonamearisto actually infrastructure and jobs are a pretty good place to 
start at improving a nation. these are places with low GDPs and as a result 
it takes less FDI to improve these nations. And there IS FDI rolling into a 
lot of these countries, as their governments stabilize after years of 
post-colonial malaise, they're beginning to take advantage of the resources 
at hand. massive chinese investment in africa in recent years is a good 
example of that. There is still a lot to be done, and Africa is behind far 
behind likes of Asia and Latin America, but there's no denying the 
improvement.
comments.author: Doctor Witten

comments.text:
No, it doesn't go a long way to improving these nations, it just means they 
produce a bit more. It takes more than a mine or a road to raise living 
standards.
comments.author: Nonamearisto

comments.text:
the point of that statistic is that these countries are improving. you said 
it yourself, even relatively small developments go a long way for improving 
these nations. no one is saying that Sierra Leone is going to overtake the 
US as the next world power =,=

comments.author: Daniel Montenegro

comments.text:
Why do you equate "poor" with "african"?

And even so, no; relatively speaking, if nothing changes in the system of 
international politics and corporate meddling, the poor WILL remain poor. I 
am from a poor country. People that come and invest here and have 
tremendous results, well, THEY have tremendous results. Of course, our 
general living conditions improve as well, slightly but steadily, but their 
returns mean that relatively speaking the wealth gap only increases. 
Let's not forget that this is capitalism, and though I'm not arguing its 
ethics or efficiency, the system is driven by PERSONAL incentive. They will 
invest if it's best for them, and generally, if it's better for them than 
for anyone else. 

Without a paradigm shift, we will remain pawns in the games of others, and 
our growth will be minimal, we still have no chance, even with higher or 
highest education.

This is not grim, this is the reality.﻿
comments.author: Dexi Antoniu
